reviewText:
They definitely learned from the first one on many things. For starters the campaign, once you complete a mission you can go back to it any time to get a higher score or the secondary or hidden objective. The speed up button, unlike the first game it actually speeds things up, and makes that 40 waves go by so much quicker. The addition of other weapons were sorely needed, I found the bombs most useful, but the flamethrower is great as well. The dig in featue is great, but not for every situation.

Unlike last time, because of being able to play any mission completed in the campaign there is no quick play. Instead you get 2 Bonus missions which are cool but not a big deal.

I rated the first one 5/10. This is definitly the better overall game. It feels like they tried to boil down what they wanted  tower defence to be and refine it from the first one.

7/10 only because I feel there isn't much long term replay grab it if it goes on sale

reviewText:
iBomber Defense Pacific, which I assume to be sort of follow up to iBomber Defense, continues the tradition of producing an incredibly bland and uninspired game though unlike the original this one does have some upsides to it.

The first thing you probably notice is that you now have slightly more choices to make than simply where to place your turrets down. Turrets have been given the Dig-In" ability which gives them increased range and firepower but limits them to a very narrow arc of fire. This is a good idea in principle but in reality all it means is that you will spend most of your time simply rotating the turret so it can fire on all enemies.

Also a new addition is an ability building that allows you to drop bombs on your enemies and while this also is a nice improvement that gives you something to do while waiting for money to build up it has little impact on the gameplay.

Perhaps the biggest improvement is the inclusion of a interest system. By building Radar Stations
date: this game's equivalent of a boost turret
recommended:
you earn a little extra income each wave depending on how much money you have. This is a nice addition that encourages minimalistic builds and opens up multiple tactics for you to choose on the harder difficulties.

Where iBomber Defense was the bare bones of a tower defense game Pacific manages to be the bare bones of a tower defense game with the bare bones of every tower defense gimmick out there except for a 3D FPS option tacked on. All the additions are nice and were solely needed but none of them are really added in properly and you still play the game feeling like you might as well be playing it in a browser.

Although iBomber Defense Pacific is great improvement over the original it is still a game you play wondering what it's doing on the PC."

reviewText:
This is an average tower defense, for 1.25€ it was an OK game.
If it is above the average free browser TD, it's way below the best PC game in the genre like Defense Grid or Plant vs Zombie.
On most levels you cannot build paths with your towers and are limited to a few emplacements. And with only 7 tower types, some of which are only unlocked in the 2nd half of the campaign. This gives for little variations and low replayability.
Basically you use similar tactics on most levels.

There are a few neat ideas, the campaign plot which follow the historical events, perks, customizable towers, surprise events. But in the end they didn't add that much.

15 hours to complete the campaign on medium difficulty. Hard difficulty don't add much.
With all perks unlocked, the game balance is partly broken. And with the proper perks replaying the campaign on hard was actually easier than the first playthrough on medium difficulty.
Decent for a low price but there are much better TDs available.

reviewText:
A simple and honest Tower Defense game, and that's it.

It has good upgrades and a great variety of levels (desert, forest and water ones), and also have some pretty decent sort of enemies types.

The gameplay is simple but it has always a second objective to reach, and it is very fun to play to complete all the goals.

The sound effects could be better but the real problem is the music... It is so annoying... I played the whole time listen to my own soundtrack or podcasts.

In the end, I recommend only for those who enjoy tower defense games (and for the ones with a Spotify/Deezer/Apple Music/Whatever account LOL).

reviewText:
I tend to hate TD games. But I'll remain unbiased in this review.

This game is alright. I enjoyed playing it at least.

It's a pretty decent port.
The HUD is pretty clean except for the big icons for towers, they seem to be way to big and cover the entire bottom right of the screen.

The options for the game are pretty bare bones. Volume controls for music and SFX only.

There is a total of 22 campaign levels with 2 bonus levels. Each level can be played on either easy, normal or hard. There are also 4 challenges on each level. There is a somewhat decent amount of content.

You'll most likely enjoy this game if you like TD games.

reviewText:
Product received for free

A pretty nice and pleasant tower defense game, one of the best i've played i must say.

The story goes like that: You are playing as the U.S. forces during the World War 2 and your enemy is the forces of Japan. The theater of the battles is the Pacific Ocean and you try step by step, battle by battle to make your way towards Manilla, the capital of Philippines. Once you reach Manilla, the campaign is over.

The game has a campaign with 22 maps, as i already mentioned, which can be played in 3 difficulty levels: Rookie for Easy, Soldier for Medium and Veteran for Hard). There are plenty of \Bonus Missions" too which are basically edited campaign maps.

Your goal is to protect your Head Quarters (HQ). Japan is sending troops

reviewText:
Tower defence games are plentiful, both paid versions and free flash games.
iBomber Defence Pacific does not do anything one of the free ones doesn't do better.

The most interesting concept it has is that some of the levels are revisited, with your existing defences still in place, for a second round where you usually fight a new type of threat in conjunction to the first set (e.g. an air raid).

If you're looking for a good tower defence game on Steam instead go for the utterly amazing Defender's Quest or the huge and innovative Creeper World 3. If you're looking for a simple tower defence game just go to an online portal like Kongregate and search for Tower Defence games there.

This game doesn't do anything wrong, it just fails to do anything special.

reviewText:
Kind of an expansion for iBomber Defense despite being packaged standalone.

It changes up things a bit and gets some things right, but goes back some steps in other places.

In Pacific, when you select a turret to place an overlay appears showing valid positions.  This was the most annoying thing missing from the original.

Pacific is a lot easier than the original too and many levels can be done with little thought except to start racking up interest asap and spamming bomb towers (which IMO are overpowered or at least the game is not well balanced with their introduction).

Overall, still good fun tower defense, but not necessarily better than the original - just different.

reviewText:
This is a simple but fun tower defense game. Gameplay is similar to the previous game in the series, iBomber Defense, but several improvements have been made.

The biggest criticism with the previous game is that gameplay became stale after 40 or so waves in a single level, and some levels were too similar to others. But in iBomber Defense Pacific there are usually only 20 or so waves per level, and each level is quite different making for better variety in gameplay.

Also, there are now secondary objectives, like having to defend an oil refinery, or having to destroy enemy bunkers. Completing secondary objectives is optional but doing so earns you points to buy upgrades.

To keep things fresh now you sometimes have to deal with enemy units that aren't rushing your base! Yes, sometimes enemy units will come out onto the battlefield and start shooting it out with your turrets. This becomes especially tricky if you're trying to defend a secondary objective: Should you put your limited resources into defending your base or defending the secondary objective?

Another improvement is that now you can drop bombs on the battlefield. Bombs are a limited use item that are gradually replenished over time. Since you'll only get a few you need to make sure each one counts. Should you use them to thin out the ranks of the baddies rushing your base? Use them to blow open supply crates to get extra resources? Use them to kill that enemy battleship that's parked outside the range of your turrets? Use them to destroy a target to complete a secondary objective? Use them to destroy the secret enemy base hidden in most levels to get bonus upgrade points? Or just start randomly dropping them on buildings to revel in sheer destruction? There are a ton of tactical choices to make!

If you like tower defense games you owe it to yourself to check out iBomber Defense Pacific!

reviewText:
iBomber Defense Pacific is a perfectly average TD game. It has all the basic TD elements you'd expect and no more. It's ported from mobile devices, so it's not as pretty as say, Defense Grid, but that doesn't matter much. The UI is simple, since it was designed to be touch controls, but it works perfectly fine on PC.

It's not great, it doesn't do anything new, it's not pretty and you won't remember anything about it in a year's time. That said, it satisfies one's TD needs. If you're jonesing for some TD and don't have any other TD games to play (yeah, right), this is an adequate way to scratch that itch.

Note: Just because this is a mobile game, doens't mean it's easy. I got my balls stomped many times because I was only half-paying attention. 5+ restarts per level should be expected (or maybe I'm just terrible at TD).

reviewText:
9.0/10 - Strong Land and Sea Tower Defense!

I love Tower Defense games and have played so many! My current gold standard for Tower Defense is Pixel Junk Monsters; this game isn't too far off that mark!

I would have loved to see some online coop with this game, but the maps are well done and sometimes really challenging. The upgrades allow you to dig in" which allows you to manually adjust the cannon or actively direct it. This keeps you on your toes and causes you to make some tough decisions.

As you level and conquer the extensive map you can rank up which is pretty fun since this is a war game! Tons of levels and achievements are available. If you like tower defense this is a must grab.

Worth the $5. I'm looking forward to putting more time into this title!

reviewText:
Yet another Tower Defense game and i belive there are more to come!

Ibomber Defense Pacific is a Typical TD game and a sequal from the Ibomber franchise (which i have had the pleasure of not playing). I cant realy tell whats so amazing and diffrent from other TD games but it is a Solid TD Game.

The Mechanic in the game is no more than place diffrent tower with diffrent specific skills to prevent enemys from reaching your Base! The towers you get to Place is the Turret a fast shooting but low dmg output, The Cannon with long range and heavy damage but slow, We got the bomb tower which slowly generate bombs that you can drop anywhere on the map, The Flamethrower who burns and slows enemys. The Comm's towers who increases the range of other towers and provides extra income.
the Missile tower who shoots medium hige damage in an area (works best in straight lines). and the last tower the Anti Air tower.

During the Missions or maps you can complete secondary objectives often killing crates or buildings on the map or defend specific objects! After the mission is complete you are awarded with points which you use to uppgrade your tower. you get more points if you complete the secondary objective and/or if you dont leak and all your towers survived.

There is also a Level progression in the game where you earn some xp after each mission, the only important thing about this is that you can unlock some perks to your own benefit. The game alows you to use up to 3 perks, the perks can increase your starting money of each level or boost the defense of your tower etc. it does help sometimes and it gives you a reason to continue play to advance in rank and increase score.

The Whole Game is good for an TD and the difficult level is well balanced through the game, but i dont think it is an amazing game.. the game whould be good on a mobile phone to kill time when your not close to your PC.
I would rate this game 4/10... i dont like TD games!

reviewText: If you like tower defense games, this one has some novel features in it. Gameplay is extremely fun. You fend off attack waves from ground, air, and water.. Some of the cool features in this game are that there are more than one route that the enemy travels to get to you, forcing you to focus on choke points first and develop out from there. There are bonuses to blow up on the map, including secrets. All units can be developed into beefier units, but also include a feature called 'Dig In' - this allows you to opt out of 360 degree attack capabilities for a cone of attack, but with greater range. You can build bomb towers to give you bombs that can work on land or water. You can construct support towers that extend the range of units in their area of effect. There are ambush attacks and other special combat scenarios, such as enemy return fire that make the game more than just a straight tower defense game. You earn points to increase maximum capability from your towers at the end of the round, depending on how well you do, PLUS you earn perks as rewards for things like 'number of bullets spent' or 'number of times you repair'.. all of these perk progressions are tracked so you can see how far along you are until the next unlock. All in all, I would have to say this is a great little tower defense game and I picked it up for $2. Awesome!

reviewText:
I like this game.
Being that its a converted iPad game I didn't have high expectations for it. You know how those usually go, cash shop hack job that is more focused on extracting money from your wallet than it is about entertaining you, so when iBomber Defense looked and played like a fully fleshed out game I was pleasantly surprised.

Now this is a tower defense game and it is very important I get this out of the way now. Their are 2 types of tower defense games; the 'do it your way' kind where you have total freedom to mix and match your towers as the game can be beaten in multiple styles or their is, 'do it our way' kind where each stage only has one solution and you need to figure it out and this game is surprisingly both.

On the lowest setting you can get away with duct taping your way through stages but if you bump the difficulty up then each stage only has one possible solution to it.
I think its a fair balance, not every game can be Kingdom Rush (which I think is an amazing TD game) although I personally hate the ones with only one solution because its more like a puzzle game at that point and thier are plenty of good puzzle games I would rather play than a TD game pretending to be one.

Personal genre gripes aside iBomber was clearly designed with gameplay first. You can even move the title screen about like in Super Mario 64. When did games stop being like this and remembering games are supposed to be fun? Instead they all take themselves super serious and end up a buggy mess on release instead.

Storyline is WW2 but really its just an excuse plot. WW2 is as easy to pick of the shelf and use as a storyline as elves, dwarfs and cyberpunk but it gets the job done. Sound effects, yeah they exist. Okay they are fine, a bomb sounds like a bomb and a turret sounds like a turret what more do you want?
Music? Strangely absent or turned so low (by default) that it seems absent. I honestly don't recall hearing any music at all but it wasn't until I started writing this review that I even noticed, maybe because I was too busy having fun.

I recommend this game and if you like TD games like Kingdom Rush(as you should, because its great!) then you will enjoy this game. it even has the 'specialize your turrets' tech tree. I tried it with touchscreen but oddly that didn't work out very well as the screen is just a bit too small for the delcate precision it requests of the user and I often accidently bombed my own turrets too many times so switched back to mouse input.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

reviewText: A fairly straightforward tower defense game.  The highlight is the upgrade system.  Each tower type can get 4 upgrades that carry through, and then 3 levels up upgrade during each map.  There are also perks that you earn and choose as you level up.  There are bombs in this one, which adds a fun and active element to each level.  The maps get longer and harder, and even on the easiest difficulty I found myself getting frustrated, so at 3 hrs in, I am taking an indefinite break.

reviewText:
This game is much better than iBomber Defense. It added background descriptions, upgrade choices, various secondary objectives, and other new features to the prequel and makes a good tower defense game which is both interesting and challenging. Although the graphics and sound effects remain almost the same as the prequel (frankly speaking, below than average in this genre at the time of release), the playability and replayability have been enhanced by a thousand mile.
For tower defense funs, this game will give you a dozen of hours of fun, even at the original price; while for other players, give this game a try when it is discounted won't hurt.

Finally, thank IndieGala for giving away this game for free.

reviewText: iBomber Defense Pacific begrudgingly earns a thumbs up from me even though a meh" would probably be more appropriate. The game is tower defense game ported from mobile platforms. It takes place in the pacific theater in WW2 where you fight the Japanese in land
date: air and sea battles. There are predetermined spots in each level where you can place defenses to repel the enemy forces (kind of like Kingdom Rush
recommended: but usually with greater concentration of hardpoints).\n\nFirst the positives. The game is probably the most strategic tower defense game I have played. There are inter dependencies between the turrets so you probably want to place them in certain configurations to maximize your income and/or damage output. So also need to pick from various perks (Fallout'esqe) and turret upgrades so your strategy on a given level can potentially change based on that. The game also lets you fast forward time and pause it if you wish; if you pause the game
voteText: you can redirect your turrets adding a strategic element (ie
helpfulPercent: "micro") that many other titles lack.\n\nAs for the negatives
votesTotal: but I guess acceptable. I found it really hard to tell the difference between enemy units so it is sometimes tough to prepare sufficiently until your turrets have engaged the enemy. My bigger gripe is that this game is $4.99 on steam vs $1.99 on the Play store. Why the PC gamer gouging that seems so prevalent with mobile game developers? Sick of these companies who do a PC release as an afterthought and still charge a big premium.\n\n"

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine
PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game

ALSO NOTE: If I (the reviewer) have played a game that has less than 1 hour of gameplay and is recommended, means that I did not enjoy it but it passed a bit of my level of expectations! Think twice before buying/playing this game
(This only applies to some games that have been recommended, not all, please read above before reading the review below)
iBomber Defense Pacific is a basic tower defense game, nothing unique or special, but still provides hours of fun if you are into tower defense games.

For a mobile game, it's a pretty decent port. The HUD is pretty clean except for the big icons for towers, they seem to be way too big and cover the entire bottom right hand side of the screen. The options for the game are pretty bare bones.

Now to the recommendation, for its full price, I would not recommend it, BUT if it is either in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game like I got it then I would recommend it.

RECOMMENDED :)  Provided it is in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game, otherwise...

NOT RECOMMENDED :(  For its full price

reviewText: DEUTSCH : Dieses Game ist für zwischendurch eine sehr gute Abwechslung. Die Einheiten sind schnell und effektiv gegen die einströmenden gegnerischen Einheiten. Dabei sollte man aber mit Vorsicht bedenken das dass Geld irgendwann mal knapp wird und man evtl. Stellungen verkaufen oder versetzen muss. Ansich ein sehr gelungenes Spiel, für Leute die wenig Zeit haben ideal !\n\nEnglish : This game is in between times a very good alternative. Your forces are fast and effective against incoming enemy troops. But be aware that you only have spare cash on your account so you may have to sell or move a station to a different location. For people with spare time this game is a great choice !

reviewText:
Funny little game, well worth it for 4.- Euro.

Be aware though that the game is VERY casual, so even if you play on hard it will be very easy aside from 2-3 situations.
You can go and hunt for perfect runs though and that gives sort of a challenge. Towers are thought trough and settings are lovely made. There's not many enemies though.

Would recommend Space Run over this one for a more challenging and a bit different tower defense. Once you have that one done I'd go for this one. Would buy again.
